nodes.text: Cross-country per capita GDP growth (1960-1985) is determined by initial human capital, initial per capita GDP, investment, fertility, government consumption, political stability, and price distortions

Method: Cross-sectional OLS regressions for 98 countries (mostly 1960-1985) using heteroskedasticity-consistent standard errors and alternative weightings; primary explanatory variables include SEC60 and PRIM60 (school-enrollment rates) and GDP60

Result: With human-capital proxies held constant, initial real per capita GDP (GDP60) has a significantly negative partial relation with subsequent per capita growth GR6085 (coefficient about -0.0075 per $1,000, s.e.=0.0012)

Result: Initial human capital proxies (secondary and primary enrollment SEC60 and PRIM60) are significantly positively associated with subsequent per capita growth (partial correlation ~0.73; coefficients significant with t-values ~3.8 and 4.4)

Claim: When both initial GDP and initial human capital are included, poorer countries catch up to richer countries only if they have higher human capital relative to their GDP level (conditional convergence)

Evidence: School-enrollment measures also predict higher physical investment ratios (private and total i/y), and higher human capital is associated with lower net fertility (FERTNET); regressions show positive coefficients of SEC60/PRIM60 on investment and negative on fertility

Result: Investment ratios (private iPriv/y and total i/y) are positively related to initial human capital and negatively related to initial GDP (consistent with convergence and with human capital raising investment)

Result: Government consumption share (gc/y) is negatively associated with per capita growth and with private investment (coefficient on gc/y about -0.12 for growth), while public investment has little robust positive effect

Result: Political instability proxies (revolutions per year REV and assassinations ASSASS) are negatively associated with growth and investment; residual correlations suggest instability reduces investment and growth but reverse causation is possible

Result: A proxy for market distortions based on deviations of PPP for investment deflators (PPIGODEV) is negatively associated with growth and with investment, suggesting price distortions reduce growth

Conclusion: Empirical evidence supports conditional convergence: holding human capital constant, initial income negatively predicts growth; human capital raises growth partly via higher investment and lower fertility; government consumption, political instability, and price distortions reduce growth; unexplained regional effects remain for sub-Saharan Africa and Latin America

Limitation: Measurement error in GDP could bias level-growth relations only if persistent over long periods; school-enrollment rates proxy flows not stocks of human capital and 1950 enrollment data quality is poorer, limiting stock inference

Claim / Evidence: Continent dummies (AFRICA and LAT.AMER.) remain significant even after controls, implying the model omits features explaining poor average growth in sub-Saharan Africa and Latin America

Assumption: School-enrollment rates and available literacy and student-teacher data reasonably proxy cross-country differences in initial human capital and education quality despite measurement problems

Method / Evidence: Robustness checks include alternative dependent periods (GR7085), inclusion of GDP70, sample restrictions, weighting by GDP or population, and use of White heteroskedasticity-consistent standard errors; main findings are stable across these checks
